conclusion: Identify the type of process from D → A in the Stirling cycle.
In a standard Stirling cycle, A → B is isothermal expansion, B → C is isochoric cooling, C → D is isothermal compression, and D → A is isochoric heating (constant volume).
Relate the thermodynamic state variables for an ideal gas at constant volume, P ∝ T.
Along D → A the pressure increases, so the temperature must increase from T_L (state D) to T_H (state A).
Connect temperature to the molecular-speed (Maxwell-Boltzmann) distribution.
The functional form of the distribution remains Maxwellian, but every characteristic speed (most-probable, mean, rms) is proportional to √T.
When the temperature rises, the peak of the curve shifts to higher speed and the peak height decreases (the curve “spreads out”).
During the isochoric heating segment D → A the gas temperature increases, so the Maxwell-Boltzmann speed-distribution curve changes: it broadens and shifts to higher molecular speeds.
